title: High Military Workforce
description: In 2020, Eritrea had 13.36% of its total labor force employed in the armed forces, one of the highest percentages globally.

title: Widespread Open Defecation in Rural Areas
description: As of 2016, 88.65% of Eritrea's rural population practiced open defecation, indicating significant sanitation challenges.

title: Limited Secure Internet Infrastructure
description: In 2023, Eritrea had only 1 secure internet server, highlighting a significant gap in digital infrastructure.

title: Low Business Regulatory Environment Rating
description: Eritrea received a rating of 1 in the CPIA business regulatory environment in 2023, indicating a challenging business climate.

title: Minimal Financial Sector Development
description: The CPIA financial sector rating for Eritrea was 1 in 2023, reflecting underdeveloped financial services.

title: Poor Budgetary and Financial Management
description: In 2023, Eritrea's CPIA rating for budgetary and financial management was 1, suggesting inefficiencies in fiscal governance.

title: Low Transparency and Accountability
description: Eritrea scored 1 in the CPIA transparency, accountability, and corruption rating in 2023, indicating governance challenges.

title: Limited Trade Openness
description: With a CPIA trade rating of 1.5 in 2023, Eritrea faces significant barriers to trade.

title: Underdeveloped Data Infrastructure
description: Eritrea's data infrastructure score was 10 out of 100 in 2023, highlighting significant gaps in statistical capacity.

title: Low Regulatory Quality
description: In 2023, Eritrea's regulatory quality percentile rank was 0.47, indicating weak regulatory frameworks.

title: High Open Defecation Rates
description: In 2016, 67% of Eritrea's population practiced open defecation, reflecting severe sanitation issues.

title: Negative Aid Flow from Switzerland
description: In 2022, Eritrea experienced a net negative aid flow of $100,000 from Switzerland, indicating a reduction in financial assistance.
